question: What are fossil fuels like coal and natural gas formed from?

content.source_1: Coal forms from accumulated plant material (peat) that is buried and altered by heat and pressure over millions of years, producing a carbon-rich rock.
content.source_2: Petroleum and natural gas are derived from the buried remains of plankton and other organisms that are converted into hydrocarbons by heat and pressure over geologic time.
content.source_3: Fossil fuels are termed “fossil” because they originate from once‑living organisms whose remains were preserved and transformed in sediments.
content.source_4: Methane and some higher hydrocarbons can be generated abiotically in Earth’s mantle and at hydrothermal vents via Fischer–Tropsch–type reactions during serpentinization; abiotic methane has been observed at sites such as the Lost City vent field.
content.source_5: Certain natural gas reservoirs exhibit elevated 3He/4He ratios, a mantle signature indicating deep, nonbiological gases migrating upward along faults into sedimentary basins.
content.source_6: Pure carbon minerals like graphite can form without biological input through metamorphic reduction of carbonate rocks; graphite is combustible and exemplifies an abiotic, carbon‑rich solid produced by geologic processes.
